item.title: Eurozone Bond Market Recovery Seen Questioned
item.description: Eurozone government bond yields rose in early trading, with Commerzbank Research saying the recovery was already faltering “with Bunds weakening—also versus Treasurys.”

item.title: German Industry Continues to Weaken
item.description: German industrial production fell 1.4% in September, a much steeper decrease than expected, marking a fourth straight month of declining output.

item.title: Engie Upgrades Outlook on Improved Third Quarter
item.description: Engie said it now expected to report non-nuclear underlying earnings of €9-€10 billion for the year after it posted increased profits for the first nine months.

item.title: UBS Reports Loss as Credit Suisse Costs Weigh
item.description: UBS swung to a wider-than-expected net loss in the third quarter, as Credit Suisse integration-related expenses weighed.

item.title: Nintendo Raises Earnings Forecasts After Profit Climbs
item.description: Nintendo raised its fiscal-year earnings forecasts after a rise in first-half net profit, thanks to the success of a Super Mario film and stronger sales.

item.title: Aramco Profits Fall on Lower Prices
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s national oil company reported a drop in third-quarter profits to $33 billion due to lower energy prices and volumes sold.

item.title: AB Foods Launches Buyback
item.description: AB Foods said it would aim to buy back £500 million in shares over the next year after its fiscal 2023 profits rose 9%.

item.title: Capgemini Backs Forecasts After Revenue Rise
item.description: Capgemini confirmed its financial targets for the year after it posted revenue growth in the third quarter, although slightly less than analysts had forecast.

item.title: MTN Maintains Outlook as Profits Rise
item.description: MTN posted higher earnings in the first nine months, helped by a 9% rise in service revenue and confirmed its expectations for the full year.

item.title: Nikkei Falls 1.3%, Dragged by Electronics, Tech Stocks
item.description: Japanese stocks ended lower, dragged by falls in electronics and tech stocks, as concerns resurfaced about costs of borrowing.

item.title: Your Pilot Has a New Job---and a Bigger Plane to Fly
item.description: The industrywide battle for pilots has jolted the slow, methodical career progress to which many were accustomed

item.title: Why So Many Controversial Supreme Court Cases Come From the Fifth Circuit
item.description: The Supreme Court has some really controversial cases on its docket —including whether domestic abusers should have access to guns and whether the abortion pill should be legal. They all came from one lower court: the Fifth Circuit. WSJ explains why.

item.title: A defiant Trump offered a combative defense of his business empire in sworn testimony, trading jabs during his civil-fraud trial with a New York judge who repeatedly rebuked him for veering off on tangents.
item.description: A defiant Trump offered a combative defense of his business empire in sworn testimony, trading jabs during his civil-fraud trial with a New York judge who repeatedly rebuked him for veering off on tangents.

item.title: Federal health officials expanded their recall of children's fruit pouches to include two more brands over fears of possible lead contamination.
item.description: Federal health officials expanded their recall of children’s fruit pouches to include two more brands over fears of possible lead contamination.

item.title: A group of Senate Republicans has made a crackdown on asylum claims at the southern border a condition for backing Biden's $106 billion request for supplemental funding for Israel and Ukraine.
item.description: A group of Senate Republicans has made a crackdown on asylum claims at the southern border a condition for backing Biden’s $106 billion request for supplemental funding for Israel and Ukraine.

item.title: The U.S. increased pressure on Israel to ease its intense bombardment of the Gaza Strip, deploying top diplomats to the Middle East in recent days, even without the release of hostages taken by Hamas, which Israel has set as the condition for any pause in its military operations.
item.description: The U.S. increased pressure on Israel to ease its intense bombardment of the Gaza Strip, deploying top diplomats to the Middle East in recent days, even without the release of hostages taken by Hamas, which Israel has set as the condition for any pause in its military operations.

item.title: WeWork filed for bankruptcy under chapter 11, capping the flexible-office-space venture's remarkable collapse after once being the nation's most valuable startup, valued at $47 billion at its peak before vacancies soared.
item.description: WeWork filed for bankruptcy under chapter 11, capping the flexible-office-space venture’s remarkable collapse after once being the nation’s most valuable startup, valued at $47 billion at its peak before vacancies soared.

item.title: U.S. stocks built on a rally that pushed major indexes sharply higher over the past week. The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow rose 0.2%, 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.
item.description: U.S. stocks built on a rally that pushed major indexes sharply higher over the past week. The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow rose 0.2%, 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.

item.title: A daily list of foreigners allowed to leave Gaza is splitting up families and causing bureaucratic headaches.
item.description: A daily list of foreigners allowed to leave Gaza is splitting up families and causing bureaucratic headaches.

item.title: Israel pushed farther into Gaza City, sending troops into an urban Hamas stronghold that is still packed with civilians after one of the most intense bombing barrages of the monthlong war.
item.description: Israel pushed farther into Gaza City, sending troops into an urban Hamas stronghold that is still packed with civilians after one of the most intense bombing barrages of the monthlong war.
